entries.answer: Memory Vault is a web application for preserving and organizing memories across four vaults: personal, learning, cultural, and future. It includes an AI assistant for Memory Vault questions and memory-based help.
Any user with an account can sign in and use Memory Vault features, including memory management and AI assistant chat.
For new users: sign in, choose a vault type, create your first memory (title + content), mark important entries when needed, then use AI Assistant for summaries and organization help.

entries.topic: Best first actions in Memory Vault
entries.answer: Best first actions are: create one memory in your main vault, add one important memory, then ask AI Assistant to summarize or categorize your entries.
The vault categories are Personal Life Vault, Knowledge and Education, Cultural Heritage, and Future Wisdom.
Personal Life Vault is treated as a private diary with PIN unlock flow in the frontend experience.
To add a memory, choose a vault, open the add-memory form, enter title and content, optionally mark it important, then save.
Memory updates are supported through PATCH /api/memories/:id, including title, content, vault_type, is_important, and favorite state.
Memory deletion is supported by DELETE /api/memories/:id and is scoped to the signed-in user.
A memory record includes id, title, content, vault_type, is_important, timestamp, and user_email. Favorite state is also supported.
Memory Vault uses JWT-based authentication. Passwords are hashed with bcrypt, and protected endpoints require a valid bearer token.
JWT tokens are issued with a 7-day expiration window.
The AI assistant endpoint is POST /api/ai/chat. It uses user memory context plus curated Memory Vault knowledge to answer related questions.
The assistant is restricted to Memory Vault-related questions. Unrelated questions are refused with a prompt to ask about Memory Vault.
The frontend has memory search that filters by title, content, and vault type.
Users can star memories as favorites and view them in a dedicated favorites list in the UI.
The frontend computes summary statistics from memories, including time-based totals and vault-based counts.
The app displays a trending section that prioritizes important non-personal memories.
Backend persistence currently uses a local JSON file named users.json with user-isolated memory collections.
The frontend calls the backend at http://localhost:3000/api and is served from the same Express server root.
When backend connectivity fails, the frontend can queue requests, retry later, and use localStorage fallback behavior.
On login, local memories can be synchronized to backend while attempting to avoid duplicates using signature matching.
The frontend includes export formatting for memory data, including CSV and plain-text output formats.
Server diagnostics include GET /api/health and GET /api/debug/config to inspect runtime status and AI configuration.
Current implementation is file-based and local-first. It does not yet include image uploads or production-scale database architecture.
